markdown.markdown:
\subsection{Geographical data} ::: paratext To control for surrounding characteristics of properties, i.e. neighbourhood characteristics, we construct variables from geographical data. We begin by constructing dummy variables characterising the area surrounding the properties, such as highways, train tracks, forests and the ocean. These dummy variables are constructed by creating a 100 meter buffer, i.e., a circle with a radius of 100 meters is created around the coordinates of properties, and if a point of an object of interest falls within the buffer zone, then the dummy variable gets the value 1 else 0. Note that the coordinates of the properties were obtained when scraping the @boliga_boliga_nodate website. Defining the area of properties, i.e., neighbourhoods can be a bit tricky as there is no consensus on the definition of what constitutes a neighbourhood in terms of meters or kilometres. Throughout this paper, we will use a 100-meter buffer size, and we will also use different buffer sizes as robustness tests. To create these dummy variables, we use the Geofabrik OSM dataset for Denmark, which is compiled data from OpenStreetMap [@geofabrik_gmbh_denmark_nodate]. Next, we calculate the road distance in minutes from the capital, i.e. Copenhagen, and the radius of the surface area from a 30-minute isochrone with a car of each property. An isochrone represents a surface area which is reachable from a given point within a specific time threshold. The intuition of taking the radius from the isochrone area is to construct a simple proxy variable to represent accessibility. We took inspiration from @biazzo_general_2019 when creating our accessibility variable. The accessibility variable used in this paper will therefore represent the radius of the surface area for each dwelling at a 30 minute time threshold with a car. In relation to this, @wahlstrom_doing_2016 used an accessibility index to account for potential spatial auto-correlations, however, they compute their accessibility as the travel time between municipalities with respect to the population of municipality of destination. To compute both our accessibility variable and the road travel time to Copenhagen in minutes for each dwelling, we utilised a docker image of the Valhalla Route Engine [@valhalla_developers_valhalla_nodate]. Valhalla, an open-source route engine, provides a range of tools for geographical data analysis, including the calculation of isochrones for points of interest and the travel time in minutes between two points [@valhalla_developers_valhalla_nodate]. In addition, we incorporate the average population density of Denmark at a 1km grid level. Eurostat provides access to population density at grid level for four census years: 2006, 2011, 2018 and 2021 [@eurostat_population_2023}. We aggregate the data from all census years, resulting in our population density variable representing the average population density at a 1 km grid level over the specified period. Table @tbl-geo_summarystatistic displays summary statistics of the geographical data utilised in our analysis. All the categorical variables i.e. the buffers, are based on a 100 meter radius. Among the insights the summary statistics conveys is the distance to the capital. The furthest distance from the capital that we calculate using Valhalla route engine is approximately 410 minutes or 6,83 hours. This point is located in the Island called Bornholm. The reason it is so far is because it involves driving to the harbour in Rønne on Bornholm, taking a ferry with the car to a town called Køge, and then driving from Køge to Copenhagen. ::: ::: {#tbl-geo_summarystatistic} ```{=html}
Continuous Variables
Variable N Mean Std. Dev. Min Pctl. 25 Pctl. 75 Max Unit
Isochrone radius 728,795 23,502.81 4,582.44 471.5563 20,640.85 26,798 35,168.41 Meters
Distance to capital 728,795 105.315 79.91995 0.8377333 26.19262 165.0298 409.5823 Minutes
Avarage population density 728,795 2,768.03 3,818.33 0.25 555.5 3,128.25 20,820.5 Number of
people
Categorical Variables (Total = 728,795):
Variable Category Frequency % of Total Variable Category Frequency % of Total

Yes 5,379 1% Yes 59,118 8%
Ocean or beach buffer No 710,742 98%
Yes 18,053 2%
``` :::

## 4.3 Geographical data \subsection{Geographical data} ::: paratext To control for surrounding characteristics of properties, i.e. neighbourhood characteristics, we construct variables from geographical data. We begin by constructing dummy variables characterising the area surrounding the properties, such as highways, train tracks, forests and the ocean. These dummy variables are constructed by creating a 100 meter buffer, i.e., a circle with a radius of 100 meters is created around the coordinates of properties, and if a point of an object of interest falls within the buffer zone, then the dummy variable gets the value 1 else 0. Note that the coordinates of the properties were obtained when scraping the @boliga_boliga_nodate website. Defining the area of properties, i.e., neighbourhoods can be a bit tricky as there is no consensus on the definition of what constitutes a neighbourhood in terms of meters or kilometres. Throughout this paper, we will use a 100-meter buffer size, and we will also use different buffer sizes as robustness tests. To create these dummy variables, we use the Geofabrik OSM dataset for Denmark, which is compiled data from OpenStreetMap [@geofabrik_gmbh_denmark_nodate]. Next, we calculate the road distance in minutes from the capital, i.e. Copenhagen, and the radius of the surface area from a 30-minute isochrone with a car of each property. An isochrone represents a surface area which is reachable from a given point within a specific time threshold. The intuition of taking the radius from the isochrone area is to construct a simple proxy variable to represent accessibility. We took inspiration from @biazzo_general_2019 when creating our accessibility variable. The accessibility variable used in this paper will therefore represent the radius of the surface area for each dwelling at a 30 minute time threshold with a car. In relation to this, @wahlstrom_doing_2016 used an accessibility index to account for potential spatial auto-correlations, however, they compute their accessibility as the travel time between municipalities with respect to the population of municipality of destination. To compute both our accessibility variable and the road travel time to Copenhagen in minutes for each dwelling, we utilised a docker image of the Valhalla Route Engine [@valhalla_developers_valhalla_nodate]. Valhalla, an open-source route engine, provides a range of tools for geographical data analysis, including the calculation of isochrones for points of interest and the travel time in minutes between two points [@valhalla_developers_valhalla_nodate]. In addition, we incorporate the average population density of Denmark at a 1km grid level. Eurostat provides access to population density at grid level for four census years: 2006, 2011, 2018 and 2021 [@eurostat_population_2023}. We aggregate the data from all census years, resulting in our population density variable representing the average population density at a 1 km grid level over the specified period. Table @tbl-geo_summarystatistic displays summary statistics of the geographical data utilised in our analysis. All the categorical variables i.e. the buffers, are based on a 100 meter radius. Among the insights the summary statistics conveys is the distance to the capital. The furthest distance from the capital that we calculate using Valhalla route engine is approximately 410 minutes or 6,83 hours. This point is located in the Island called Bornholm. The reason it is so far is because it involves driving to the harbour in Rønne on Bornholm, taking a ferry with the car to a town called Køge, and then driving from Køge to Copenhagen. ::: ::: {#tbl-geo_summarystatistic} ```{=html}
